STATE OF MICHIGAN
GRETCHEN WHITMER DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES ELIZEBETH HARTEL
GOVERNOR DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE DIRECTOR
July 21, 2022
Brandon Hannah
Ennis Center for Children Inc.
20100 Greenfield Road
Detroit, MI 48235
RE: License #: CB740315326
Investigation #: 2022C0201015
Ennis Center for Children - Port Huron
Dear Mr. Hannah:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MSA and your
contract.
611 W. OTTAWA  P.O. BOX 30664  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov/lara  517-335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the local office at (248) 975-5053.
Sincerely,
Pinkey Brown, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-3012
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF LICENSING AND REGULATORY AFFAIRS
BUREAU OF COMMUNITY AND HEALTH SYSTEMS
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB740315326
Investigation #: 2022C0201015
Complaint Receipt Date: 05/05/2022
Investigation Initiation Date: 05/06/2022

Licensee Name: Ennis Center for Children Inc
Licensee Address: 20100 Greenfield Road
Detroit, MI 48235
Licensee Telephone #: (313) 342-2699
Administrator: Brandon Hannah, Administrator
Licensee Designee: Robert Ennis, Designee
Name of Facility: Ennis Center for Children - Port Huron
Facility Address: 222 Huron Avenue
Port Huron, MI 48060
Facility Telephone #: (810) 990-1424
Original Issuance Date: 10/06/2011
License Status: REGULAR
Effective Date: 04/06/2022
Expiration Date: 04/05/2024

Program Type: CHILD PLACING AGENCY, PRIVATE
1

II. ALLEGATION(S)
Violation
Established?
Foster Care Worker failed to file a 3200 when they were made Yes
aware of concerns of neglect. Foster care agency has
allowed Foster Youth to remain in placement with safety
concerns due to lack of placement options. Foster Care
Worker failed to follow protocol and has disregarded policy
multiple times.
Additional Findings No
III. METHODOLOGY
05/05/2022 Special Investigation Intake
2022C0201015
05/06/2022 Special Investigation Initiated - Telephone
Discuss the allegation with the reporting source.
05/06/2022 Contact - Telephone call made
Discuss the allegation with the Director.
06/08/2022 Contact - Telephone call made
With the Reporting Source.
06/08/2022 Contact - Document Received
From the reporting Source.
06/08/2022 Contact - Face to Face
With the Director of the agency.
06/10/2022 Contact - Document Received
From the Director of the agency.
06/28/2022 Comment
2

Review documentation in MiSACWIS regarding Foster Youth case
record.
06/30/2022 Comment
Preliminary exit.
ALLEGATION:
Foster Care Worker failed to file a 3200 when they were made aware of
concerns of neglect. Foster care agency has allowed Foster Youth to remain
in placement with safety concerns due to lack of placement options. Foster
Care Worker failed to follow protocol and has disregarded policy multiple
times.
INVESTIGATION:
 Foster Youth, age 16, was not interviewed for this investigation as her
whereabouts were unknown during this investigation. She was on AWOL status.
 Foster Youth is an MCI ward and at her last known address, she was living with
an unlicensed relative.
 Foster Youth was placed with the agency on 3/17/2021.
 I reviewed Foster Youth updated service plan dated 11/14/21 – 2/11/22. The
report documented Foster Youth AWOL status as well as contacts with the
sheriff office and the State police coordinating efforts to locate Foster Youth.
 It should be noted that the agency Foster Care Worker assigned to Foster Youth
case no longer works for the agency as she resigned from her position January
of 2022. She was not interviewed for this investigation.
I interviewed the Reporting Source regarding this allegation. She reported she had
several concerns regarding the private agency case management. She said Foster
Youth was absent without legal permission (AWOLP) from 10/2/2021 – 3/21/2021
and again from 3/22/2022 – 3/25/2022, and 4/5/2022. She said when Foster Youth
was located, she was placed with unlicensed relatives. The Reporting Source
alleged that the agency did not file a missing person report regarding the AWOL of
Foster Youth. The Reporting Source reported that Foster Youth was located on
3/28/2022 at the unlicensed relative home and admitted that she had a verbal
altercation with her relative and that she left the home on her home and without the
approval of her relative. The Reporting Source reported that Foster Youth reported
to her during her AWOL, she was living with her cousin, grandparents, and
biological mother.
The Reporting Source said a special investigation was initiated on the unlicensed
relative home and during the duration of the investigation several concerns such as
Foster Youth getting into verbal altercations and leaving without permission, safety
planning and appropriate placement of Foster Youth. The Reporting Source said
despite the concerns with the unlicensed relative, the agency placed Foster Youth
3

back into the home of the unlicensed relative. The Reporting Source said a Team
Decision Meeting (TDM) was scheduled to discuss Foster Youth case. She said
she learned at the TDM that while Foster Youth was on AWOL status Foster Youth
was engaging in delinquent and risky behaviors causing additional concern for
Foster Youth overall well-being as well as her future and improper supervision.
I interviewed the agency Director regarding the allegations. She reported she was
discussing the placement of Foster Youth with a DHHS Worker and informed the
DHHS Worker that she wanted to schedule a TDM to discuss Foster Youth case
and placement. The Director said due to Foster Youth consistently going AWOL,
she felt her agency could not keep Foster Youth safe, and she questioned whether
Foster Youth was placed appropriately given her behaviors of constantly going
AWOL. The Director said she requested a 30-day removal of Foster Youth from
her agency at the TDM. The Director said there were a lot of disagreement between
her and the DHHS Worker at the TDM and when she (The Director) expressed her
concerns about Foster Youth behaviors and finding another placement for Foster
Youth. The DHHS Worker filed a 3200 while the meeting was occurring and
accused her agency of knowing information about Foster Youth and her current
placement and not filing a 3200 report. The Director said she filed a 3200 report on
05/06/2022 but that the DHHS Worker filed the 3200 report during the TDM
regarding the agency concerns about Foster Youth.
The Director provided a timeline of Foster Youth’s behavior while place with their
agency. A summary is as follows:
 03/15/2022 Foster Youth found after being AWOL for 6 months.
 03/17/2022 Foster Youth placed with Unlicensed relative.
 03/22/2022 Foster Youth ran from Unlicensed relative home. Missing person
report filed DHHS, and law enforcement was contacted, and the following email
was sent to Guardian Ad Litem (GAL), Program Manager DHHS, POS Monitor,
Foster Youth attorney, Agency Foster Care Worker, DHHS Foster Care
Supervisor, and the agency Vice President.
 A home call was completed at the relative home on 03/23/2022. She said the
relative reported that Foster Youth left voluntarily, that she was concerned that
Foster Youth was using Fentanyl and would not abide by her rules. She said the
Foster Youth was threatening to hurt the relative and was having contact with her
biological mother. The relative reported that Foster Youth was at her aunt’s
home.
 The Director said clearances were ran on the relative and her boyfriend due to
their Child Protective Services and criminal history, her agency was not
approving placement.
 On 03/23/2022 Foster Youth was spoken to by her agency worker and Foster
Youth shared that she and unlicensed relative argued, and the relative boyfriend
threw her things out of the house, and she was living with her cousin. The Foster
4

Youth told her worker that she was told she could not stay there. The Foster
Youth said she talked with her grandfather and that he is willing for the Foster
Youth to stay at his home.
 The grandparents are willing to keep Foster Youth temporarily. Efforts will be
made to file an Incorrigibility Petition tomorrow in Sanilac County DHHS office. A
5770 will be completed prior to her going to her grandfather’s tonight.
 03/24/2022 Contact was made with DHHS worker.
 04/05/2022 Centralized Intake was contacted regarding Foster Youth AWOL.
Worker was told that since there is an active investigation there was no need to
file another complaint.
 04/05/2022 Email to DHHS RE: AWOL.
 04/22/2022 Met with Foster Youth and unlicensed relative at their home.
Reviewed placement paperwork, completed DOC, discussed school, counseling,
medication, MYOI, medical/dental needs and employments. Foster Youth is
willing to "try out" counseling again but is not sure she wants to be back on
medication. Foster Youth knows she must follow the household rules, is not to
have contact with her mother, needs to tell relative where she is and when she
will return, and will not use substances. Foster Youth would like to attend Port
Huron High School and see what she can do for credit recovery.
 04/26/2022 Phone call from relative boyfriend. He reported he and his girlfriend
got into a screaming match. Foster Youth called the police, no one was arrested,
he left the home and that the unlicensed relative may be evicted. A Safety plan
was put in place.
 04/27/2022 Home visit made. Unlicensed relative stated she and her boyfriend
were arguing, safety plan was put in place for Foster Youth.
 05/05/2022 at 10:00 am TDM held, requested by the private agency.
Placement stability TDM was held. Counseling Services, communication with
agency, education, medical/dental appointments, and placement were all
discussed with the participants.
 05/06/2022 The agency contacted Centralized Intake regarding concerns from
the TDM.
The Director said DHHS, and her agency agreed with moving Foster Youth to
another placement due to safety concerns but Foster Youth attorney and the GAL
who was in the TDM did not support the removal of Foster Youth and they wanted
her to remain at the home of the unlicensed relatives. The Director said her agency
was having a hard time placing Foster Youth and they could not find her a different
placement. She said all parties including the referee on the case was aware of the
concerns the agency had with Foster Youth and her placement. The Director said at
the conclusion of the TDM it was decided that Foster Youth would be removed from
the unlicensed relative home. Foster Youth could not live with her foster parents.
5

The agency would complete the residential paperwork and send the information to
DHHS. She said the paperwork was completed and sent to DHHS. The Director
said DHHS requested that Foster Youth case be returned to the Department, and
they will find her a suitable placement. She said Foster Youth was removed from
the unlicensed relative home on 5/25/2022 and placed in an Independent Living
Placement. On 6/30/2022, Foster Youth was on AWOL status.
I reviewed the documentation the agency had on Foster Youth case. There were
documents and case worker notes detailing the AWOLs of Foster Youth and each
time she went AWOL. A missing person report was filed with the local law
enforcement and all parties pertinent to the case was notified.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12214 Compliance with 1975 PA 238.
An agency shall develop a written plan and implement the
plan to assure compliance with 1975 PA 238, MCL 722.621,
and known as the child protection law.
ANALYSIS: It was documented in case records missing person reports and
the efforts the agency made in attempting to locate Foster
Youth. This information was also documented in MiSACWIS. In
review of documentation, protocols were followed regarding
filing a missing person report, notification to pertinent individuals
associated with the case. However, the agency failed to file a
3200 report prior to requesting a TDM regarding Foster Youth
behaviors of having a verbal altercation with the unlicensed
relatives and the police being called. DHHS filed the 3200 the
day of the TDM, 5/5/2022 and the agency filed a 3200 of the
same issues on 5/6/2022 regarding Foster Youth.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6

IV. RECOMMENDATION
It is recommended that Ennis Center for Children license remain unchanged pending
an acceptable corrective action plan.
07/21/2022
________________________________________
Pinkey Brown Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
July 21, 2022
________________________________________
Linda Tansil Date
Area Manager
